identificationModule.briefTitle: Evaluating the Episodic Future Thinking Intervention for Reducing Cigarette Consumption in Cigarette Smokers
identificationModule.officialTitle: Pilot Study of Episodic Future Thinking Among Cigarette Smokers

descriptionModule.briefSummary: This clinical trial evaluates the effectiveness of active episodic future thinking (EFT) stimuli for reducing cigarette consumption in cigarette smokers. EFT is an innovative framing method shown to significantly activate brain regions involved in future thinking, planning, and other executive functions. Active EFT stimuli are positive events, unrelated to smoking, that participants anticipate, look forward to, and can vividly imagine happening up to 1 year in the future. Control EFT stimuli are positive past events, unrelated to smoking, that participants can vividly remember happening in the recent past. Active EFT stimuli may help reduce cigarette consumption among cigarette smokers by exposing them to personally relevant future oriented stimuli.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
PRIMARY OBJEECTIVE:

I. To evaluate the efficacy of episodic future thinking (EFT) for smoking cessation.

OUTLINE: Participants are randomized to 1 of 2 arms.

ARM I (ACTIVE): Participants receive the active EFT stimulus and use the iCOquit Smokerlyzer carbon monoxide monitor on study.

ARM II (CONTROL): Participants receive the control EFT stimulus and use the iCOquit Smokerlyzer carbon monoxide monitor on study.

armGroups.label: Arm 1 (active EFT)
armGroups.description: Participants receive the active EFT stimulus and use the iCOquit Smokerlyzer carbon monoxide monitor on study.
interventionNames: Other: Medical Device Usage and Evaluation

armGroups.label: Arm II (control EFT)
armGroups.description: Participants receive the control EFT stimulus and use the iCOquit Smokerlyzer carbon monoxide monitor on study.

interventions.name: Smoking Cessation Intervention
otherNames: Smoking and Tobacco Use Cessation Interventions

interventions.name: Smoking Cessation Intervention (control)
otherNames: Smoking and Tobacco Use Cessation Interventions

interventions.name: Medical Device Usage and Evaluation
interventions.description: Use iCOquit Smokerlyzer carbon monoxide monitor

primaryOutcomes.measure: Concentration of carbon monoxide on breath
primaryOutcomes.description: Will be measured by ICOquit Smokerlyzer

secondaryOutcomes.description: participants will be guided to imagine the situational and sensory details for each of the stimuli until the vividness scores are ≥ 4 on a scale of 1-5 (1=very low, 5=very high).

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Smoke \>= 10 cigarettes daily
* \> 32 on the Vividness of Visual Imagery Questionnaire (VVIQ)
* No regular use of other tobacco products
* In possession of a smartphone with text messaging capabilities

  * Willing to quit smoking in the next 30 days
  * Low socioeconomic status

Exclusion Criteria:

* Unable or unwilling to provide verbal consent
* Unable or unwilling to provide data to the research team
* Current use of nicotine replacement therapy, bupropion, or varenicline
* Use of drugs of abuse in the past 30 days
* Living in the same household as a participant already enrolled in this study
